Very Late to this party: When you put in the zinc powder the finest powder granules, the dust of the dust if you will, and the repeated stirrings, probably created a (colloidal?) suspension of lead crystals that were light enough to stay suspended in the solution. When you added the zinc pellets you both created a chemical reaction and a micro-fine rain of the suspended led. Basically there was probably a fairy snowfall of lead crystals that gave structure and bulk to the deposition products. The chunkiness of the result probably also kept more of the surface area of the zinc reactively exposed for longer.
So basically a significant fraction (most of?) the lead in the big container was a suspension and not actually lead acetate any more.
That's a guess from mechanical intuition and not chemical genius. I do systems theory, not chemistry. YMMV.

PS.I'd be interested to know if I'm right or wrong or a strong maybe.

I at first was wanting to get into collab projects with other YouTubers, but with my regular engineering day job and my aerospace 3D graphics freelance schedule, plus the many other parts of my life as a family man and keeping up with other projects I have going on, I have an excess of compounds I've made which have a shelf life such as potassium ferric oxalate (K3[Fe(C2O4)]3). One problematic issue of this particular compound is that it is photosensitive and decomposes forming CO2 upon exposure to light. I have no immediate use for it and I'd rather see someone put it to use. Most of my K3[Fe(C2O4)]3 has been purified three times through recrystalization. Some of it has not, but is stored and labelled in a separate light protected container. I still have approximately 600ml of solution to evaporate and crystalize the remaining K3[Fe(C2O4)]3.

I don't see any legal concers over the particular chemicals I'm referring since they are widely available online from eBay, Amazon and just about any science company that will sell to industry and individuals. I think this metal sponge is formed from tiny filaments of metal strands and crystals that interwoven into this spongy texture. I suspect this spongy metal texture is formed in redox reactions in aqueous solution. I have seen this spongy metal in electrolysis experiments using very high current density (around 2 to 2.5 ampere per cm^2 - as at that time I have no mechanisms to control the power the electrolysis). Besides lead, I have seen copper and iron sponge from high current electrolysis as well.

I'm really new to chemestry, only been reading for like 2 month on my own, so my skills are VERY basic.
Anways, to my quesiton(s).
As dichlorometane is really really hard to get where I live (Scandinavia), and I needed a non-polar solvant I tried out the haloform reaction.
NaClO + C3H6O -> CHCl3
Not sure why but I only got a 12% yeald, perhaps I pushed the temperature to low throughout the reaction (maxed out at 14C - I kept it really cold), is it the solubility in cold water, or should I use another metal ketone, any ideas ?
From there to my next question, as I said, dichlorometane is really hard to get here, and I was reading some on making it, it seems to requier very high tempertures, pressures etc. (dont try at home stuff).
But in my mind I was thinking this: CHCl3(g) + Na(s) + H2O(l) -> CH2Cl2 + NaCl + O2

When I balanced the formula I came to 4 moles of chloroform (trichlorometane), 4 moles of Sodium and 2 moles of water.
The water (under 100 degrees C) should react with the sodium metal which in turn should react with the trichlorometane gas (over 61.2 degrees C), making dichlorometane, salt and oxygen.
After wich it should be easy enough to get rid of the salt and anything unreacted with a fractional distillation slightly over 39.6 degrees C but well beneth 61.2 degrees C.

Will this work or is the H2O bond to strong to split-off the hydrogen atoms from the oxygen, and if that is the case is there any way around that (I'm thinking eletrolysis perhaps, and mix the hydrogen gas with the tricholomethane gas but still initiate the reaction with water) ?
Or fail for some other reason that I dont know about with my very limited chemestry knowlidge ?
